newsitem.title: JAPAN: INTERVIEW-Imagineer to boost education software.
newsitem.headline: INTERVIEW-Imagineer to boost education software.

text.p: Japanese game software maker Imagineer Co Ltd is gearing up to boost business in software for the education market through further tie-ups with Japanese publishers.

Imagineer president Takayuki Kamikura told Reuters in a recent interview that the company hopes to expand its revenue from educational software to about half its total earnings in the coming three or four years.
In late May, the company said it saw group sales growing to 12.47 billion yen for the current fiscal year, which started in April, against the previous year's 8.38 billion yen.
Its group net profit was predicted to total 590 million yen for 1997/98, against the previous year's 405 million yen.

In 1996/97, Imagineer, in cooperation with Obunsha Corp, a Japanese publisher known for its college entrance examination text books, released three education software titles for Nintendo Co Ltd's, portable game player Gameboy, which has 15 million users across Japan.
Imagineer sold a total 40,000 of the three titles in 1996/97 and plans to tie up with other Japanese publishers to release 15 titles this year, Kamikura said.
The company aims to sell a total 300,000 of the 15 new titles, he added.
Kamikura also said the company is preparing to establish a school in Tokyo by the end of this year where students will use digital software in their studies.

He said: "The Japanese education system still forces children to memorise, while the Americans teach students how to search for information using computers. In this sense, Japan is far behind. There is a need to show students how to work in a digital environment."
Although he did not elaborate on plans for the school, he said he had visited schools in the United States, Israel and Denmark for research.

Imagineer plans to release 82 titles including eight game software titles for the 64-bit game machine Nintendo 64, 10 for Sega Enterprises Ltd's Sega Saturn game player and six for Sony Corp's PlayStation this business year, he said.
The company aims to double its total software sales to 2.8 million units this business year from the previous year.
